vocabularyList.name: bartender
vocabularyList.text: a person who works in a bar
vocabularyList.note: Bartenders in the United States may work in a large variety of bars. These include hotel bars, restaurant bars, sports bars, gay bars, piano bars, and dive bars. Also growing in popularity is the portable bar, which can be moved to different venues and special events.

vocabularyList.name: brewer
vocabularyList.text: a person or company that makes beer

vocabularyList.name: ice tea
vocabularyList.text: served in a glass with ice, it can refer to any tea that has been chilled or cooled
vocabularyList.note: There are two traditional iced teas in the United States – Iced Tea and Sweet Tea. The only variation between them is sugar. Southerners swear by their traditional sweet ice tea and drink it by the gallons.

vocabularyList.name: brew
vocabularyList.text: a coffee made by pouring hot water over coffee grounds

vocabularyList.name: coffee
vocabularyList.text: a beverage consisting of a decoction or infusion of the roasted ground or crushed seeds

vocabularyList.name: arabica
vocabularyList.text: coffee or coffee beans from the most common type of coffee plant
vocabularyList.note: Arabica coffee originates from Ethiopia and was first cultivated in Yemen, and documented by the 12th century. Coffea arabica is called ‏بُنّ‎ (būnn) in Arabic, borrowed from the Oromo 'Buna'.

vocabularyList.name: beverage
vocabularyList.text: any potable liquid, especially one other than water, as tea, coffee, beer, or milk
vocabularyList.note: The first documentary evidence of alcoholic beverages was written in Sumerian around 3200 BC, most certainly concerns beer rather than wine production and employs a specific pictograph for beer itself – an outline of a clay vessel marked with short, diagonal lines.

content.text: Do you have non dairy option?
May I see the menu please?
I have a ... to go/for here
How would you like to pay?
Today's specials are on the board.

I have a ... to go/for here
How would you like to pay?

keyVocabularyList.name: Antibodies
keyVocabularyList.description: Antibodies are specialized, Y-shaped proteins that bind like a lock-and-key to the body's foreign invaders whether they are viruses, bacteria, fungi or parasites.
sample: Breastfeeding provides infants with antibodies.
Antibodies are specific to the agent causing their response.

keyVocabularyList.name: Bacteria
keyVocabularyList.description: very tiny living things that have only one cell, some of which can cause diseases.
sample: Washing hands regularly help can help kill bacteria.
Some bacteria makes people sick, but others are totally harmless.

keyVocabularyList.name: Fecal Matter
keyVocabularyList.description: solid excretory product evacuated from the bowels
sample: The child may not even be aware that he or she has defecated until the fecal matter has already passed.
The fecal matter then continues its journey across to the transverse colon.

keyVocabularyList.name: Immune System
keyVocabularyList.description: The immune system is a complex network of cells and proteins that defends the body against infection.
sample: The immune system is our body's shield against infection.
The virus suppresses the body's immune system.

keyVocabularyList.name: Sanitize
sample: Sanitize food preparation surfaces regularly.
As water can carry PRRS virus it is important to sanitize water systems.

keyVocabularyList.name: Coddle
keyVocabularyList.description: To treat with extreme or excessive care or kindness
sample: To molly coddle someone or some pet is to really fuss over them; to over indulge them.
You can watch the birds cozy up with their eggs or coddle their newly hatched chicks.

keyVocabularyList.name: Euro
keyVocabularyList.description: The unit of money used in most European Union countries
sample: I collected 24p and 10 Euro cents, and my friend got a lovely pink cardigan.
The proposed Iranian bourse would establish a fourth oil marker, denominated by the euro.

keyVocabularyList.name: Juncture
keyVocabularyList.description: A particular point in events or time.
sample: At this juncture (October 1895) came overtures to the leading Uitlanders.
We are at a crucial juncture in the HIV epidemic.

keyVocabularyList.name: Rationale
keyVocabularyList.description: A set of reasons or a logical basis for a course of action or a particular belief.
sample: The plan was criticized for its lack of rationale.
The rationale behind the changes is not at all evident.

keyVocabularyList.name: Sound
keyVocabularyList.description: Vibrations that travel through the air or another medium and can be heard when they reach a person's or animal's ear.
sample: There was no sound to be heard anywhere throughout the country.
They don't sound at all alike to me.

keyExpressionsList.name: According To
keyExpressionsList.description: a phrase used to mean ‘as stated by’, ‘as reported by’ or ‘based on’
sample: According to a Forbes article, Atomix of New York City is one of the ten coolest restaurants for 2021.
According to the weather news, there is a 50% chance of rain in the afternoon.

keyExpressionsList.name: To Cut Down (on Something)
keyExpressionsList.description: If you cut down on something or cut down something, you use or do less of it.
sample: I am trying to cut down on sugar this month. I would like to lose some weight before going on holiday.
I have to cut-down the tree outside my office window in order to see the beautiful view.

keyExpressionsList.name: To Have Something Against Someone
keyExpressionsList.description: Dislike someone or something for particular reason
sample: You should do something about the problem.
Something was pushing its way through the bushes.

keyExpressionsList.name: Under the Weather
keyExpressionsList.description: Slightly unwell or in low spirits.
sample: Toby said you've been under the weather.
Jackson is a bit under the weather.

keyExpressionsList.name: To Set Up
sample: The house rules had been set up to protect the girls from him.
Both of us tried to remember details of Quinn's actions when he set up a session.
